abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the UPPER Krishna (Phase II) Irrigation
            Project (UKP II) in India. It is part of a long-term program
            to irrigate one million hectares in Karnatakas arid
            northern districts which started in 1956. Intended to extend
            irrigation downstream and continue construction of Almatti
            Dam for additional storage of irrigation water, in
            accordance with projected irrigation needs, while completing
            the resettlement of families displaced by Narayanpur and
            Almatti and the irrigation network. The project was rated
            unsatisfactory and had satisfactory performances by the Bank
            and borrower. Lessons learned where that economic
            rehabilitation plans should be taken into account when
            establishing Resettlement Centers. The time frame required
            for economic rehabilitation is much greater than that for
            physical resettlement and the resettlement process will need
            support and careful monitoring until this is completed.
            Resettlement cannot be implemented with a blueprint
            approach. Project design has to allow a flexible, process
            approach aimed at achieving resettlement objectives rather
            than delivering predetermined inputs. The cost of not
            leaving irrigated land as planned and of not building the
            drains where needed will be vary high compared to the modest
            costs avoided. Leaving the canals open and allowing
            over-irrigation when there is surplus water during the
            initial construction period encourages high-water consuming
            crops and risks waterlogging and salinization. Finally, the
            absence of the sector work and formulation of a coherent
            irrigation sector strategy left the project
            conceptualization vulnerable despite intensive preparation
            and appraisal.
